title: UCMDB Integration
content:
Introduction

Service Management provides an integration with the UCMDB that synchronizes Service Asset & Configuration Management (SACM) information. The UCMDB integration uses the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) to connect to an external UCMDB to synchronize Actual Services, Service Components, System Elements and Assets to the Service Management repository. This document provides detailed information regarding the configuration of this integration.

This information includes:

  • Installing the OPB Agent
  • Creating an Endpoint
  • Configuring SSL for OPB
  • Configuring the UCMDB Endpoint
  • Verifying Data Synchronization
  • Troubleshooting 

Installing the OPB Agent

Login to the desired tenant within Service Management with a user that has Tenant Admin privileges. If you login to the Service Portal, switch to the Agent Interface.

From the main menu, navigate to the Integration area under Administration > Utilities.

Ensure the Agents section is selected (from the header menu bar) and click on Download agent to copy the agent configuration to a local location on your computer.

Copy the Agent configuration file to the server running the On-Premises Bridge software. Perform the install process which is described in this link specifically the section on Installing the OPB:

Installing the OPB

On the OPB server, go to the following location: C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\opb

Double click the credential_mng_ui file.

The Credentials Manager will open, allowing you to create Endpoint credentials for Service Management. Click the New button.

Select the type of Endpoint being created, for this it would be UCMDB 10.20. Click OK.

Enter a name for the Credentials and provide the username and password the OPB will use to connect to the UCMDB. Once all details are completed, click Save.

If the OPB Agent isn’t running, bring up the Services on the OPB server and start the On-Premises Bridge Agent service.  

Creating an Endpoint

Login to the Service Portal with an Admin User and again open the Agent Interface. Once the Dashboard has opened, go to the main menu and select Administration -> Utilities -> Integration.

Note: This assumes all previous steps to install OPB Agent have already been completed on an appropriate server.

Click on the Endpoints section in the header menu. Within the Endpoints screen, click on Add. A new window will appear asking for the Endpoint Type, Endpoint name and Running on agent. Fill in the details and click Add.

This will create the Endpoint for UCMDB on the OPB.

If UCMDB isn’t using SSL then skip the next section and go straight to Configuring the UCMDB Endpoint.

Configuring SSL for OPB

Before the OPB and UCMDB can communicate, SSL certificates need to be added to the Java keystores of the respective servers. Otherwise, errors will be reported when trying to test the connection between the Service Management Endpoint and UCMDB.

Export UCMDB Server Certificate

Run the following command on the UCMDB Server by opening a command prompt. If a server.keystore file already exists, then remove it before running this command:

From <UCMDB-Installation-Folder>\bin\jre\bin, run the following command:

keytool.exe -genkey -alias hpcert -validity 365 -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 -keystore C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\conf\security\server.keystore

Export the keystore file to be used by the Probe and OPB using the following command (when running this command, the UCMDB Keystore password will be required based upon what was used during install):

keytool.exe -export -alias hpcert -keystore C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\conf\security\server.keystore -storepass <Password> -file C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\conf\security\ucmdbserver.cert

Copy the ucmdbserver.cert file from the C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\conf\security folder to relevant folders on the Probe and OPB servers.

If using the Integration Service on UCMDB Server, it would be as follows:

C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\integrations\conf\security

Probe Server it would be:

C:\UCMDB\dataflowprobe\conf\security

For OPB place in the following location:

C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\3rd-party\jre\lib\security

Import UCMDB Server Certificate

The certificate file needs to be loaded into the probe server(s) for them to communicate to the UCMDB Server via SSL over port 8443. This is done by running the following command:

From <UCMDBProbe-Installation-Folder>\bin\jre\bin, run the following commands:

keytool.exe -import -trustcacerts –keystore C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\integrations\conf\security\server.truststore -storepass <password> -alias hpcert -file C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\integrations\conf\security\ucmdbserver.cert

keytool -import -file <Certificate-File-Name> -keystore -Alias <Probe-Installation-Folder>\conf\security\HPProbeTrustStore.jks

When prompted for the password enter logomania

Finally the UCMDB Server Certificate needs to be loaded into the OPB truststore. This is done running the following command:

keytool.exe -import -keystore "C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\3rd-party\jre\lib\security\cacerts" -alias hpcert -file "C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\3rd-party\jre\lib\security\ucmdbserver.cert"

When prompted for the password enter changeit

Once the UCMDB certificate has been uploaded to the OPB, restart the On-Premises Bridge Agent Service.  

Configuring the UCMDB Endpoint

Once the OPB is configured and the UCMDB certificate uploaded into the Java keystores, one final configuration is required. The Endpoint created earlier needs to be configured. Go to the Endpoint and click on Configure. Enter the environment details for the external UCMDB similar to the example below:

Click on Test Connection. If everything is configured correctly then you should see a success message:

Click Save to keep the configuration settings. The OPB will then deploy a package to the UCMDB Server. This will configure an Integration Point within UCMDB along with the adapter that will be used to map data from UCMDB to Service Management.

To see the Integration Point in UCMDB, go to Data Flow Management -> Integration Studio. You should see an Integration Point with the name of the OPB Agent and the Tenant ID for Service Management. From there you can view the jobs that will run under the Integration Point and see the CIs that are passed from UCMDB to Service Management.

Once the Integration Point has been deployed, the sync will take place, running the TQL queries that comprise the Integration Job within the Integration Point. When all jobs have finished successfully, the output from these jobs will be sent to OPB and stored in the following location:

<On_Premise Bridge Folder>\Product\Util\Repository\

When a Sync takes place it pulls in the data held in the task_input_data and sends it across to the task_output_data. Once all data has been loaded into Service Management, these folder locations should be empty.

 

Verifying Data Synchronization

To determine what data has been imported into Service Management, go to the UCMDB Endpoint.

Open one of the Sync tasks to see exactly what has been added to Service Management.

The devices and relationships added to Service Management are then available to view.

Within Service Management, it’s possible to check exactly what has been added to the SACM module. From the main menu click on Build -> Service Asset & Configuration

You can then search for the devices that were synchronized from UCMDB.

After clicking the Edit button, you can see exactly what properties have been passed to Service Management from UCMDB

From the top of the device screen, click on Show Impact. You can then see the relationships from the UCMDB Service Model have been passed to Service Management.

Apply update for using Aviator in cross-domain integration

If Aviator capability is enabled, update the Suite configuration to allow seamless cross-domain integration You can skip this configuration update if you already applied it during Service Management  installation or upgrade.

The placeholder used in the commands in this section are as follows:

  • <release name>: The release name.
  • <suite namespace>:  Unique namespace of the ESM deployment.
  • <ESM helm chart path>: Path to the helm charts tar file. This file is located in the charts folder.

Complete the following steps to update the configuration.

  1. Run the following command. If it returns SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN_COOKIE_SAMESITE: None, the cross‑domain setup is complete and you can skip the remaining steps. 
    kubectl get cm itom-bo-configmap -n <suite namespace> -o yaml | grep "SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN_COOKIE_SAMESITE: None"
  2. Get the deployment YAML values into a file named my-values.yaml. 
    helm get values <release name> -n <suite namespace> > my-values.yaml
  3. Run the following command to apply configuration update. 
    helm upgrade <release name> <ESM helm chart path> -n <suite namespace> -f my-values.yaml -f <ESM helm chart path>/samples/enableSMAXAuthTokenSameSiteNone-values.yaml
  4. Restart the pods. 
    kubectl rollout restart deployment itom-bo-login-deployment -n <suite namespace>

Aviator limitations in cross-domain integration scenarios

The following limitations apply to Aviator users in cross-domain integration scenarios. An example of cross-domain integration scenario is when your Suite deployment is integrated with other products such as AI Operations Management (AIOM) or Universal Discovery and CMDB (UD/UCMDB) for information exchange.

  • If you open Aviator in a private browsing mode, such as Incognito in Chrome, it may not return any responses to your requests.

  • While using Aviator, if the session times out, you may be asked to log in again.

Troubleshooting

When troubleshooting the Integration between Service Management and UCMDB there are a number of places to look for issues.

The first is within Service Management. Specifically, looking at the Integration to check for any errors reported either with the Agent or on the actual UCMDB Endpoint. If there are errors being shown here, most likely there is a problem with the OPB. In this case, log on to the OPB Server and check the following log locations:

<OPB Install location>\On-Premises Bridge Agent\product\log\ucmdb-10.20

From this location, check the following logs which should help to show if there is a communication problem from the OPB to UCMDB:

  • ucmdb-10.20.log.0
  • error.log
  • output.log

If there is a problem with UCMDB, it is worth checking the probe\integration Service that is used for the integration. If the probe is offline for any reason, this will impact on the integration and no synchronization will take place.

On the probe server, check the following log location for any errors:

<UCMDB Install Location>\DataFlowProbe\runtime\log

If the integration still isn't successful, contact the Service Management Support team and create a ticket. Be sure that the OPB logs and configuration files are included.
